messageBody:
Hi Jean

I was pondering your first issue:

> 1. I need to know the correct result from the other way around and
sometimes it's hard to find another way.

I am not quite sure if I fully understand what you mean. Are you
saying, to write good test, you need two different "approaches" to
solve the problem under test? Like in the following, trivial
example:

public int multiply(int a, int b) {
return a * b;
}

public void testMultiply() {
// test the expected result, "the other way round"
assertEquals(5 + 5, x.multiply(5, 2);
}

I can see that this can get quite hard for non-trivial problems.

If this is what you meant, I think I have good news: In believe this
rigorous approach to unit testing is not necessary. It's perferctly
accaptable to just write the test as:

assertEquals(5 * 2, x.multiply(5, 2);

The point of automated unit testing is not to prove algorithmic
correctness but just to check real behavior against expected
behavior. In my opinion, the main benefit of _automated_ unit
testing is to be able to re-run the tests after implementation
changes. And, after implementation changes, you cannot be sure
if "the other way round" is still another way or if it has actually
become "the way". So don't bother in the first place, and save a lot
of time and pain.

Again: For me, automated unit tests are primarily like an insurance
against quality degradation when I change code. They are less
important to prove correctness of the initial version of the code I
write. I tend to spend more time changeing existing code than
writing new code, so that's fine for me.

Bottom line is, forget about the "other way round" issue. ;-)

Hasko
